entry.title: Ransomware TeslaCrypt
entry.content:
Ransomware TeslaCrypt ‚Äì Static & Dynamic Analysis

Introduction

This blog presents a detailed static and dynamic analysis of the TeslaCrypt ransomware.
The objective is to understand its internal structure, behavior, network communication, and environmental impact due to energy consumption.

Static Analysis

Fingerprinting

File Name Size (bits) Meaning Architecture
1 290,816 Packed sample 32-bit
2 263,680 Unpacked version 32-bit

We focus on the unpacked sample for analysis.

Hash Analysis

  • SHA-256
    3372c1edab46837f1e973164fa2d726c5c5e17bcb888828ccd7c4dfcc234a370

  • MD5
    209a288c68207d57e0ce6e60ebf60729

The executable starts with MZ, confirming it is a Windows PE file.
Compile timestamps align with known TeslaCrypt campaigns (timestamps may be falsified).

Hash & PEStudio Output

Imported APIs (Malicious Indicators)

Category API Function Potential Malicious Purpose
Evasion & Stealth IsDebuggerPresent Used to change behavior or exit to avoid analysis.
Sleep Delays execution to "time out" automated sandboxes.
VirtualAlloc Process Injection or unpacking hidden code.
Data Theft (Stealer) OpenClipboard / GetClipboardData Clipboard Hijacking
GetDIBits / CreateCompatibleBitmap Screen Capturing.
Information Gathering EnumProcesses Lists all running programs to identify security software (Antivirus).
GetLogicalDriveStringsW Identifies connected drives (USB, Network shares).
GetTokenInformation Checks user privileges.
Persistence & Execution RegSetValueExW Writes to the Windows Registry to ensure the malware starts automatically on every reboot.
ShellExecuteW / CreateProcessW Launches secondary payloads, command scripts, or hidden system tools.
CopyFileW Moves the malware binary to a "safe" hidden directory (like System32 or AppData).
Network & Exfiltration InternetConnectA Establishes a connection to a remote Command & Control (C2) server.
HttpSendRequestA Exfiltration.
InternetSetCookieW Used to steal or manipulate web session cookies to hijack online accounts.
Anti-Forensics DeleteFileW Used to delete the original installer or temporary "stolen data" files after they are uploaded cover tracks.

Imports Table Screenshot

Library Analysis

DLL Risk Level Role
WININET.dll Critical C2 communication
ADVAPI32.dll High Privilege & registry
PSAPI.dll High Process enumeration
KERNEL32.dll Medium Core execution
USER32.dll Medium User activity
GDI32.dll Medium Screen capture
SHELL32.dll Medium Program execution
1. Network & Data Theft (WININET.dll & ole32.dll)
These libraries allow the malware to act like a web browser. It uses these to send stolen data (logins, cookies, files) to a remote server. The ole32.dll library helps it interact with browser objects or other COM-based applications (like Outlook or Excel) to extract data.
2. System Reconnaissance (PSAPI.DLL & KERNEL32.dll)
These are used to "scout" the infected machine. PSAPI (Process Status API) is specifically used to see which programs are currently running. Malware uses this to look for tools like Wireshark, Process Hacker, or Windows Defender to avoid being caught.
3. User Spying (USER32.dll & GDI32.dll)
These handle the visual and interactive parts of Windows. Used to "hook" user actions. USER32 monitors typing/clicking, while GDI32 and MSIMG32 "paint" a copy of your screen into a file to be stolen.
4. Privilege Escalation (ADVAPI32.dll)
This library manages security and registry access. The malware checks for "System" or "Admin" rights. If missing, it may trigger UAC prompts or exploit vulnerabilities to gain higher permissions.

String Analysis

Malware Analysis: CryptoLocker v3

String Classification & Evidence Overview

üìÑ Binary Artifacts (PE Header)

  • This program cannot be run in DOS mode
  • RichkM
  • .text (Code Section)
  • .rdata (Read-only Data)
  • .data (Initialized Data)
  • .rsrc (Resources)

üí∞ Ransomware Evidence

  • CryptoLocker-v3
  • HELP_TO_DECRYPT_YOUR_FILES.txt
  • HELP_TO_DECRYPT_YOUR_FILES.bmp
  • CryptoLocker.lnk
  • key.dat | log.html | help.html
  • vssadmin delete shadows /all

üåê Network & Exfiltration

  • 34r6hq26q2h4jkzj.onion
  • tor2web.fi | tor2web.org
  • 50.7.138.132 (C2 IP)
  • Subject=Payment&recovery_key=%s...
  • Subject=Ping | Subject=Crypted
  • WININET.dll

üîê Cryptographic Operations

  • RSA-2048 | SHA-256 | RIPE-MD160
  • CryptAcquireContextW
  • CryptGenRandom | CryptEncrypt
  • SECG curve over a 256 bit prime field
  • CAutoBN_CTX : BN_CTX_new()
  • EncodeBase58

üéØ Encryption Targets

  • Documents: .docx, .xlsx, .pptx, .accdb
  • Media: .jpeg, .asset, .unity3d
  • Databases: .db, .mdbackup
  • Games: .mcgame, .wotreplay, .rgss3a

üñ•Ô∏è GUI / User Interaction

  • Your personal files are encrypted!
  • Enter Decrypt Key
  • Check Payment
  • Click to copy Bitcoin address
  • mshta.exe (HTML Application Host)

üõ°Ô∏è Persistence & Evasion

  • Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run
  • IsDebuggerPresent
  • CreateMutexW
  • EnumProcesses | CreateToolhelp32Snapshot
  • Process32First / Next

Static strings confirm TeslaCrypt / CryptoLocker family ransomware.
Static string analysis reveals that the sample is a fully functional ransomware belonging to the TeslaCrypt/CryptoLocker family. The malware implements strong cryptographic routines, including RSA-2048 and SHA-256, to encrypt a wide range of user files across multiple file formats. It enumerates drives and processes, deletes Volume Shadow Copies to prevent recovery, and establishes persistence via registry Run keys. The presence of Tor and Tor2Web URLs, Bitcoinrelated encoding, and extensive ransom instructions indicates a complete payment and decryption workflow. These strings strongly confirm ransomware behavior without requiring execution.

Static Analysis Conclusion

Static analysis confirms this sample as a fully functional TeslaCrypt ransomware.
It includes encryption, persistence, network communication, and victim interaction mechanisms.
Dynamic analysis is required to observe runtime behavior and system impact.

Key Evidence

  • RSA-2048 & SHA-256 encryption
  • Tor & Tor2Web URLs
  • Bitcoin payment workflow
  • File extension targeting
  • Shadow copy deletion
  • GUI ransom messages

Dynamic Analysis

Ransom Note & GUI


Process Behavior

  • Opens files with write permission
  • Overwrites original data
  • Deletes original files
  • Runs continuously

Process Monitoring

File System Modifications

  • Creation of ransom notes
  • Encryption of files (.jpg, .txt, etc.)
  • Renaming encrypted extensions
  • Startup persistence enabled

Network Behavior Analysis

Network analysis was performed using INetSim.

Observations

  • DNS queries to Tor2Web gateways
  • Onion service communication attempts
  • Bitcoin-related requests
  • Payment verification traffic

Network Logs

Energy Consumption Analysis

Baseline System (Clean)

CPU

Performance Counter Instance Machine Mean (%) Minimum (%) Maximum (%)
% C1 Time _Total DESKTOP-42QFN1J 70 0 87
% C2 Time _Total DESKTOP-42QFN1J 0 0 0
% C3 Time _Total DESKTOP-42QFN1J 0 0 0
% DPC Time _Total DESKTOP-42QFN1J 0.104 0 3
% Idle Time _Total DESKTOP-42QFN1J 70 0 87
% Interrupt Time _Total DESKTOP-42QFN1J 0.13 0 3
% Privileged Time _Total DESKTOP-42QFN1J 13 0 84
% Processor Time _Total DESKTOP-42QFN1J 18 0.458 100
% User Time _Total DESKTOP-42QFN1J 5 0 40
  • Avg Utilization: 18%
  • Duration: 300 seconds
  • CPU Load Index: 18 √ó 300 = 5,400

Disk

Disk Number Reads / sec Kb / Read Writes / sec Kb / Write
0 32.9 17 12.5 224
  • Writes/sec: 12.5
  • Disk Load Index: 3,750
  • Data Written: ~820 MB

Total Baseline Energy Index:
9,150

Infected System (Ransomware Active)

CPU

Performance Counter Mean (%) Min (%) Max (%)
% C1 Time 52 1 94
% C2 Time / % C3 Time 0 0 0
% DPC Time 0.893 0 7
% Idle Time 52 1 94
% Interrupt Time 0.37 0 4
% Privileged Time 30 0 82
% Processor Time 37 0.691 99
% User Time 7 0 45
  • Avg Utilization: 37%
  • CPU Load Index: 11,100

Disk

Disk # Reads / sec Kb / Read Writes / sec Kb / Write
0 356.7PEAK I/O 22 267.5ENCRYPTION STREAM 64
  • Writes/sec: 267.5
  • Disk Load Index: 80,250
  • Data Written: ~5.1 GB
Metric Value
Writes/sec 267.5 ops/s
KB/Write 64 KB
Duration 300 seconds
Total Data Written 5,136,000 KB (~4.9 GB)

Total Infected Energy Index:
91,350

Baseline vs Infected Comparison

State Energy Index
Clean 9,150
Infected 91,350

‚âà 10√ó increase in energy consumption

Final Conclusion

TeslaCrypt ransomware not only encrypts user data but also causes severe CPU and disk stress, leading to significant energy waste.
This highlights ransomware as both a cybersecurity threat and an environmental concern, increasing carbon emissions through unnecessary system load.

Disclaimer

This analysis is strictly for educational and research purposes.
No live systems were harmed during testing.
Source: Original PDF Analysis Report :contentReference
entry.summary: tatic and dynamic analysis of TeslaCrypt ransomware, including API behavior, string evidence, network communication, and energy consumption impact.

entry.title: üõ°Ô∏è Malware Analysis Lab Setup Guide
entry.content:
A malware analysis lab allows you to safely study malware behaviour inside an isolated environment without risking your real machine or network.
This guide walks you through setting up a complete lab using:

  • FLARE VM (Windows malware analysis platform)
  • REMnux (Linux reverse-engineering distro)
  • INetSim / FakeDNS for fake internet responses
  • VMware / VirtualBox isolated networks

All steps include screenshots from my own setup.

üß∞ Requirements

Before you begin, ensure you have:

  • 70+ GB disk space for FLARE VM
  • 8 GB RAM minimum (16 GB recommended)
  • A system capable of running 2‚Äì3 VMs
  • Basic understanding of VMs
  • Patience ‚Äî FLARE VM installation takes hours

üì• Files You Need to Download

  1. Windows ISO
  2. VMware Workstation or VirtualBox
  3. REMnux .ova appliance
  4. FLARE VM install script

ü™ü Setting Up FLARE VM (Windows)

Step 1: Download the Installer

Open PowerShell as Administrator and run:

(new-object net.webclient).DownloadFile(
'https://raw.githubusercontent.com/mandiant/flare-vm/master/install.ps1',
"$([Environment]::GetFolderPath('Desktop'))\install.ps1"
)

Unblock-File .\install.ps1
Set-ExecutionPolicy Unrestricted -Force

.\install.ps1
Step 2: Choose Your Packages
After running the installer, FLARE VM will show a package selection screen:

Click Install.

‚ö†Ô∏è Note: Installation takes many hours (sometimes 6‚Äì12 hours). Your VM will reboot many times ‚Äî this is completely normal.

setting W.S

turn off windows defender firewall in both dir.

and enable [turn off windows antivirus]

network setup

üåê Network Setup (Virtual Machines)

This part is extremely important because malware MUST NEVER touch your real network.

You will configure a Host-Only network, meaning:

  • Malware cannot access the internet
  • FLARE VM ‚Üî REMnux can communicate privately
  • INetSim can simulate fake internet services

üñ•Ô∏è Network Setup (VirtualBox)

Step 1: Open VirtualBox Network Manager

Step 2: Create Host-Only Network

Use:

IPv4 Address: 10.0.0.1

Subnet Mask: 255.255.255.0

Step 3: Configure DHCP

Use:
nginx 
Copy code 
Server Address: 10.0.0.2 
Server Mask:    255.255.255.0 
Lower Bound:    10.0.0.3 
Upper Bound:    10.0.0.254

üñ•Ô∏è Network Setup (VMware Workstation)

Step 1: Open Virtual Network Editor Go to:

Copy code Edit ‚Üí Virtual Network Editor

Step 2: Create a Host-Only Network (VMnet3 recommended) Use:

Subnet IP:     10.0.0.0
Subnet Mask:   255.255.255.0
DHCP enabled 
VMware automatically assigns .1 and .2, so you don't need to set server IP manually.
starting ip add: 10.0.0.3
ending ip add: 10.0.0.254

üêß Installing REMnux

Open Import Appliance in VMware or VirtualBox

Select the remnux.ova file

Choose storage location

Start the VM

setting network

cd /etc/inetsim
sudo nano inetsim.conf

üéâ Your Malware Analysis Lab Is Ready!

You now have:

  • FLARE VM fully installed
  • REMnux imported and configured
  • Host-only isolated network
  • Fake internet simulation (INetSim + FakeDNS)
  • Safe environment for analyzing malware

You can now begin:

Static malware analysis

Dynamic analysis

Network traffic monitoring

Behavioural analysis
entry.summary: A complete beginner-friendly guide to building a safe, isolated malware analysis lab using VMware, FLARE VM, and REMnux. Includes network setup, INetSim configuration, and fake internet simulation.

entry.title: how to make persistence drive
entry.content:
I‚Äôll show you how to create a Kali Linux persistent drive, but you can use this method to make a persistent drive for any Linux version. I‚Äôve personally tried it with Parrot OS and Ubuntu.

  • Requirements
  1. any storage devices more then 20gb.
  2. computer ü§∑üèº‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è.
  • Preparation of Drive

  1. Download linex live iso file. LIVE iso file is very importent

  2. download etcher balena to write image on drive.

  3. open etcher balena to etch iso file to your drive

Your drive is now ready‚Äîyou can boot and use Linux on any compatible computer.

adding presistence

  1. boot your linex drive with live system mode.

  2. Open GParted on your Linux system. .\

  3. make new partiton name :- ** persistence **

  4. your terminal will look like this

open terminal

 if you have multipal drive then name will change
 first step code
 sudo su
  
 wipefs /dev/sda

 wipefs -o 0x8001 -f /dev/sda

 second step code

 mkdir -p /mnt/usb

 mount /dev/sda3 /mnt/usb

 echo "/ union" > persistence.conf

-now boot drive on persistence mode
entry.summary: Linux is my favorite operating system, but I often forget how to set up my Linux drive. This post is a simple guide to help anyone who wants to install Linux and keep their data safe during the process.

entry.title: ZUZE_GAME_OVER
entry.content:
ZUZE GAME OVER VIRUS

Static and Dynamic Malware Analysis Report

STATIC ANALYSIS

Fingerprinting

File Name Size (bits) Meaning Architecture
epig.exe 319968 Packed sample 32-bit
epig_unpacked.exe 261120 Unpacked version 32-bit

We will be diving into the unpacked sample for analysis.

Hash Analysis

  • SHA-256
    09E9FB8BEB798F2C17A311D59C0A44D9E815D6CAD8EA4FEADD77A66D4D3706B5

  • MD5
    36ADE9194C6F05CCEE041CEF0A5C7DA7

  • HEX Header
    4D 5A 90 00 03 00 00 00 04 00 00 00 FF FF 00 00 B8 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 40 00 00 00 00 00 00 00

PEStudio Observation

The file is identified as a Windows executable because it starts with the MZ header.

Imported Libraries

  • Secur32.dll ‚Äì Authentication and security packages
  • WS2_32.dll ‚Äì TCP/IP network communication
  • CRYPT32.dll ‚Äì Cryptographic operations
  • WININET.dll ‚Äì HTTP/FTP communication
  • NETAPI32.dll ‚Äì Network and user management
  • IPHLPAPI.dll ‚Äì Network configuration details
  • ADVAPI32.dll ‚Äì Windows Registry manipulation

Functional Breakdown of the Malware

The malware likely performs the following actions:

  • Command & Control (C2): Uses socket and HTTP-based communication to contact attacker servers.
  • Data Exfiltration & Encryption: Encrypts stolen data using Windows cryptographic APIs.
  • System Profiling: Collects network, system, and user information.
  • Persistence & Stealth: Modifies registry keys to survive system reboots.

IMPORTS

Process Injection

  • VirtualAllocEx
  • WriteProcessMemory
  • CreateRemoteThread
  • SetThreadContext
  • GetThreadContext

Stealth & Hidden Desktop

  • CreateDesktopW
  • SwitchDesktop
  • SetThreadDesktop
  • OpenInputDesktop

Privilege Escalation

  • AdjustTokenPrivileges
  • OpenProcessToken
  • LookupPrivilegeValueW
  • CreateProcessAsUserW

Persistence

  • RegSetValueExW
  • RegCreateKeyExW
  • SetFileAttributesW

Information Theft

  • GetKeyboardState
  • GetClipboardData
  • GetUserNameExW

Network Communication

  • send
  • recv
  • WSAEventSelect
  • getaddrinfo

Encryption (C2)

  • EncryptMessage
  • DecryptMessage
  • CryptImportKey
  • CryptVerifySignatureW

Anti-Analysis

  • OutputDebugStringA
  • CreateToolhelp32Snapshot
  • Process32NextW

STRINGS

Encryption

  • CryptAcquireContextW
  • CryptCreateHash
  • CryptHashData
  • CryptUnprotectData
  • PFXImportCertStore
  • certs\%s\%s_%02u_%02u_%04u.pfx

Data Handling

  • CreateFileW
  • WriteFile
  • ReadFile
  • DeleteFileW
  • MoveFileExW
  • GetTempPathW
  • GetTempFileNameW
  • %s.cab
  • flashplayer.cab

Environment Awareness

  • IsWow64Process
  • GetNativeSystemInfo
  • GetVersionExW
  • GetSystemMetrics
  • GetDiskFreeSpaceExW
  • GetAdaptersAddresses
  • GetDriveTypeW
  • GlobalMemoryStatusEx

Surveillance

  • screenshots\%s\%04x_%08x.jpg
  • image/jpeg
  • GDI32.dll
  • PrintWindow
  • BitBlt
  • GetDC

NOTE (Static Analysis)

Static analysis indicates that the Zeus Game Over sample is a 32-bit Windows PE executable with extensive capabilities for:

  • Process injection
  • Credential theft
  • Encrypted C2 communication
  • Registry-based persistence
  • User surveillance

The unpacked version exposes clear indicators of malicious intent, warranting further dynamic and behavioral analysis.

DYNAMIC ANALYSIS (Unpacked Sample)

Registry & Persistence Strings

  • SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion
  • SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Internet Explorer
  • ProfileList\%s
  • ProfileImagePath
  • Start Page
  • InstallDate
  • Run

C2 Communication Strings

  • HTTP/1.1
  • POST /write HTTP/1.1
  • GET /test HTTP/1.1
  • Host: default
  • Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded
  • Authorization
  • X-Real-IP

Data Theft Indicators

  • username="%s", password="%s"
  • Account_Name
  • SMTP_Email_Address
  • Google Talk
  • Windows Mail
  • Mozilla\Firefox
  • Internet Explorer

Process Injection APIs

  • VirtualAllocEx
  • WriteProcessMemory
  • CreateRemoteThread
  • NtCreateThread
  • NtCreateUserProcess
  • ReadProcessMemory
  • VirtualProtectEx

Execution Overview

The unpacked sample (epig_unpacked.exe) was executed in an isolated FLARE-VM environment with INetSim.

Observations

  • No child processes spawned
  • No registry persistence detected
  • No files created or modified
  • No network traffic observed

Analysis Conclusion (Unpacked Sample)

The unpacked variant showed minimal runtime behavior and lacked loader or installation logic.
It is likely intended for static analysis or reverse engineering only.

Analyst Note

The absence of malicious behavior is a valid finding.
Zeus Game Over commonly relies on loader-based execution, which is removed in unpacked samples.

Dynamic Analysis Summary (Packed Sample)

  • Sample executed briefly and terminated
  • Only standard DLL loading observed
  • No persistence, injection, or network activity
  • Likely incompatible with modern Windows environments

Final Conclusion

Although full runtime behavior was not observed, static and partial dynamic analysis confirm the sample as Zeus Game Over malware.
Execution failure is attributed to legacy design and environment incompatibility, not analysis error.

Source: Original PDF Analysis Report :contentReference
entry.summary: This blog presents a detailed static and dynamic malware analysis of the *Zeus Game Over (ZUZE)* sample. The analysis focuses on PE structure, imported APIs, encryption mechanisms, persistence indicators, and runtime behavior observed in an isolated FLARE-VM environment.

entry.title: Welcome to Jekyll!
entry.content:
You‚Äôll find this post in your _posts directory. Go ahead and edit it and re-build the site to see your changes. You can rebuild the site in many different ways, but the most common way is to run jekyll serve, which launches a web server and auto-regenerates your site when a file is updated.

To add new posts, simply add a file in the _posts directory that follows the convention YYYY-MM-DD-name-of-post.ext and includes the necessary front matter. Take a look at the source for this post to get an idea about how it works.

{
  "firstName": "John",
  "lastName": "Smith",
  "age": 25
}
Syntax Description Test Text
Header Title Here‚Äôs this
Paragraph Text And more

The world is flat.

  • Write the press release
  • Update the website
  • Contact the media

H2O

X2

I need to highlight these very important words.

  • Chris Wayne

‚ÄúThis is a quote which should be followed‚Äù Also I think this sentence is quite long. more quote text to come

  • Chris Wayne

Single line quote

However, these are bulletpoints:

  • To add new posts, simply add a file in the _posts directory that follows the convention YYYY-MM-DD-name-of-post.ext and includes the necessary front matter. Take a look at the source for this post to get an idea about how it works.
  • another point
  • that‚Äôs it

However, these entries should not be styled:

  1. an entry
  2. another entry
  3. that‚Äôs another entry

Jekyll also offers powerful support for code snippets:

def print_hi(name)
  puts "Hi, #{name}"
end
print_hi('Tom')
#=> prints 'Hi, Tom' to STDOUT.

hi

hi3

hi5

An interesting fact on the economy of modern America

Pictures look like this:

Check out the Jekyll docs for more info on how to get the most out of Jekyll. File all bugs/feature requests at Jekyll‚Äôs GitHub repo. If you have questions, you can ask them on Jekyll Talk.

#jekyll #dash now officially supports both, dark and light theming. Enjoy!https://t.co/4evp9pX2Ws pic.twitter.com/vOQCZjGKic

— „ÄΩÔ∏è…™…¢·¥ú·¥á ü (@bitbrain_) August 27, 2019
entry.summary: this article explains something and gives a brief introduction.
